values.description:
This pull request introduces the first iteration of `ignition-cmake`. A detailed migration document can be found in [MIGRATION.md](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/src/CMakeRefactor/MIGRATION.md). I recommend viewing it with something that supports markdown.

Here's a brief overview of the advantages of converting to `ignition-cmake`:

1. Much simpler, cleaner, and more maintainable cmake scripts for each `ignition` project

2. Fixes or improvements to the build system are quickly propagated to all `ignition` projects

3. We are now automatically generating a variety of headers and files which would otherwise be a chore to maintain (e.g. we can correctly generate each project's pkgconfig and `-config.cmake` files without needing any maintenance).

4. Our packages will be fully relocatable.

5. Package and directory names will be versioned appropriately, allowing multiple major versions to be installed on a machine at the same time.

Note that this PR satisfies all the feature requests brought up [here](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-seed/issues/3/) in `ignition-seed`.

Examples of projects that use `ignition-cmake` can be found on [branch CMakeRefactor-3 of ignition-math](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/src/CMakeRefactor-3) (the -3 is because it targets ignition-math3) and [branch CMakeRefactor of ignition-common](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/src/CMakeRefactor).
values.title: First version of ignition-cmake

summary.raw:
This pull request introduces the first iteration of `ignition-cmake`. A detailed migration document can be found in [MIGRATION.md](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/src/CMakeRefactor/MIGRATION.md). I recommend viewing it with something that supports markdown.

Here's a brief overview of the advantages of converting to `ignition-cmake`:

1. Much simpler, cleaner, and more maintainable cmake scripts for each `ignition` project

2. Fixes or improvements to the build system are quickly propagated to all `ignition` projects

3. We are now automatically generating a variety of headers and files which would otherwise be a chore to maintain (e.g. we can correctly generate each project's pkgconfig and `-config.cmake` files without needing any maintenance).

4. Our packages will be fully relocatable.

5. Package and directory names will be versioned appropriately, allowing multiple major versions to be installed on a machine at the same time.

Note that this PR satisfies all the feature requests brought up [here](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-seed/issues/3/) in `ignition-seed`.

Examples of projects that use `ignition-cmake` can be found on [branch CMakeRefactor-3 of ignition-math](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/src/CMakeRefactor-3) (the -3 is because it targets ignition-math3) and [branch CMakeRefactor of ignition-common](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/src/CMakeRefactor).
summary.html:
This pull request introduces the first iteration of ignition-cmake. A detailed migration document can be found in MIGRATION.md. I recommend viewing it with something that supports markdown.

Here's a brief overview of the advantages of converting to ignition-cmake:

  1. Much simpler, cleaner, and more maintainable cmake scripts for each ignition project

  2. Fixes or improvements to the build system are quickly propagated to all ignition projects

  3. We are now automatically generating a variety of headers and files which would otherwise be a chore to maintain (e.g. we can correctly generate each project's pkgconfig and -config.cmake files without needing any maintenance).

  4. Our packages will be fully relocatable.

  5. Package and directory names will be versioned appropriately, allowing multiple major versions to be installed on a machine at the same time.

Note that this PR satisfies all the feature requests brought up here in ignition-seed.

Examples of projects that use ignition-cmake can be found on branch CMakeRefactor-3 of ignition-math (the -3 is because it targets ignition-math3) and branch CMakeRefactor of ignition-common.

values.description:
This PR build on Pull Request #1 to also enable ignition projects to specify component libraries using `ign_add_component(~)`.

There are a few ~~non-backwards-compatible~~ changes between this and Pull Request #1. These changes will be backwards-compatible, but they will print out developer warnings with instructions on how to migrate to the new system. You can find explanations of them in the diff of the migration document, but the short list is:

1. `ign_add_library(${PROJECT_LIBRARY_TARGET_NAME} ${sources})` is replaced by `ign_create_main_library(SOURCES ${sources})`

2. `ign_install_all_headers(~)` no longer accepts the argument `ADDITIONAL_DIRS` (all subdirectories will be included by default), and instead you may specify subdirectories to exclude using `EXCLUDE_DIRS`.

3. Remove the `ign_install_library()` function completely, because it is no longer used.

~~For now, I'm targeting the `CMakeRefactor` branch to make this easier to review. I'll change it to target `default` after Pull Request #1 is merged.~~
values.title: Creating project components [Ready For Review]

summary.raw:
This PR build on Pull Request #1 to also enable ignition projects to specify component libraries using `ign_add_component(~)`.

There are a few ~~non-backwards-compatible~~ changes between this and Pull Request #1. These changes will be backwards-compatible, but they will print out developer warnings with instructions on how to migrate to the new system. You can find explanations of them in the diff of the migration document, but the short list is:

1. `ign_add_library(${PROJECT_LIBRARY_TARGET_NAME} ${sources})` is replaced by `ign_create_main_library(SOURCES ${sources})`

2. `ign_install_all_headers(~)` no longer accepts the argument `ADDITIONAL_DIRS` (all subdirectories will be included by default), and instead you may specify subdirectories to exclude using `EXCLUDE_DIRS`.

3. Remove the `ign_install_library()` function completely, because it is no longer used.

~~For now, I'm targeting the `CMakeRefactor` branch to make this easier to review. I'll change it to target `default` after Pull Request #1 is merged.~~
summary.html:
This PR build on Pull Request #1 to also enable ignition projects to specify component libraries using ign_add_component(~).

There are a few non-backwards-compatible changes between this and Pull Request #1. These changes will be backwards-compatible, but they will print out developer warnings with instructions on how to migrate to the new system. You can find explanations of them in the diff of the migration document, but the short list is:

  1. ign_add_library(${PROJECT_LIBRARY_TARGET_NAME} ${sources}) is replaced by ign_create_main_library(SOURCES ${sources})

  2. ign_install_all_headers(~) no longer accepts the argument ADDITIONAL_DIRS (all subdirectories will be included by default), and instead you may specify subdirectories to exclude using EXCLUDE_DIRS.

  3. Remove the ign_install_library() function completely, because it is no longer used.

For now, I'm targeting the CMakeRefactor branch to make this easier to review. I'll change it to target default after Pull Request #1 is merged.

values.description:
Since the ignition projects are using modern C++ features, we need ways to inform dependents about which C++ standard they should be using when compiling against our libraries. The built-in cmake method for this is the "compile features" target property. There are certain compile features which are known by cmake, and we can specify which features our program needs, and cmake can infer what flags to pass the compiler so that it provides the features we ask for. For convenience, `ignition-cmake` groups these features into two lists, one for C++11 and one for C++14.

However, there is one feature in each list which Microsoft Visual Studio 2017 C++ compiler does not yet support, so this pull request removes those from the lists and allows us to support MSVC 2017. If we are interested in supporting earlier versions of MSVC, then we may need to do additional tests to see which features those earlier versions do not yet support.

This branch of `ign-cmake` has been tested on Windows and is working for `ign-math` (branch: `CMakeRefactor-default`) and `ign-common` (branch: `CMakeRefactor`).
values.title: Ignoring C++ features that are not yet supported by MSVC

The built-in cmake method for this is the "compile features" target property. There are certain compile features which are known by cmake, and we can specify which features our program needs, and cmake can infer what flags to pass the compiler so that it provides the features we ask for. For convenience, `ignition-cmake` groups these features into two lists, one for C++11 and one for C++14.

However, there is one feature in each list which Microsoft Visual Studio 2017 C++ compiler does not yet support, so this pull request removes those from the lists and allows us to support MSVC 2017. If we are interested in supporting earlier versions of MSVC, then we may need to do additional tests to see which features those earlier versions do not yet support.

This branch of `ign-cmake` has been tested on Windows and is working for `ign-math` (branch: `CMakeRefactor-default`) and `ign-common` (branch: `CMakeRefactor`).
summary.html:
Since the ignition projects are using modern C++ features, we need ways to inform dependents about which C++ standard they should be using when compiling against our libraries. The built-in cmake method for this is the "compile features" target property. There are certain compile features which are known by cmake, and we can specify which features our program needs, and cmake can infer what flags to pass the compiler so that it provides the features we ask for. For convenience, ignition-cmake groups these features into two lists, one for C++11 and one for C++14.

However, there is one feature in each list which Microsoft Visual Studio 2017 C++ compiler does not yet support, so this pull request removes those from the lists and allows us to support MSVC 2017. If we are interested in supporting earlier versions of MSVC, then we may need to do additional tests to see which features those earlier versions do not yet support.

This branch of ign-cmake has been tested on Windows and is working for ign-math (branch: CMakeRefactor-default) and ign-common (branch: CMakeRefactor).

values.description: This adds a multi value arg `GENERATED_HEADERS` which allows headers which cannot exist in the source directory to be included by `${IGN_DESGINATION}.hh`. Whoever generated the header is responsible for installing them.
values.title: Add GENERATED_HEADERS to ign_install_all_headers()

summary.raw: This adds a multi value arg `GENERATED_HEADERS` which allows headers which cannot exist in the source directory to be included by `${IGN_DESGINATION}.hh`. Whoever generated the header is responsible for installing them.
summary.html: This adds a multi value arg GENERATED_HEADERS which allows headers which cannot exist in the source directory to be included by ${IGN_DESGINATION}.hh. Whoever generated the header is responsible for installing them.

values.description:
We found some fascinating issues that arise when toolchains (which get called before the top-level `cmake_minimum_required(VERSION ~)` call) redefine the native cmake functions or macros. Effectively, none of the cmake policies will be set as desired inside of those macros or functions.

This fixes that issue, and also preemptively fixes any possible issues that may arise from a user who may have a lower minimum require version setting than what we expect.

At the moment, the minimum required cmake version of a config file will automatically take on the value of the minimum required cmake version of the ignition project it belongs to. We can change that behavior if desired, since the config-file cmake version doesn't necessarily need to be tied to the project's cmake version, but I think we generally intend to use the same cmake version across all projects anyway, so it's probably a moot point.
values.title: Explicitly set the cmake_minimum_required policy version for package config files

summary.raw:
We found some fascinating issues that arise when toolchains (which get called before the top-level `cmake_minimum_required(VERSION ~)` call) redefine the native cmake functions or macros. Effectively, none of the cmake policies will be set as desired inside of those macros or functions.

This fixes that issue, and also preemptively fixes any possible issues that may arise from a user who may have a lower minimum require version setting than what we expect.

At the moment, the minimum required cmake version of a config file will automatically take on the value of the minimum required cmake version of the ignition project it belongs to. We can change that behavior if desired, since the config-file cmake version doesn't necessarily need to be tied to the project's cmake version, but I think we generally intend to use the same cmake version across all projects anyway, so it's probably a moot point.
summary.html:
We found some fascinating issues that arise when toolchains (which get called before the top-level cmake_minimum_required(VERSION ~) call) redefine the native cmake functions or macros. Effectively, none of the cmake policies will be set as desired inside of those macros or functions.

This fixes that issue, and also preemptively fixes any possible issues that may arise from a user who may have a lower minimum require version setting than what we expect.

At the moment, the minimum required cmake version of a config file will automatically take on the value of the minimum required cmake version of the ignition project it belongs to. We can change that behavior if desired, since the config-file cmake version doesn't necessarily need to be tied to the project's cmake version, but I think we generally intend to use the same cmake version across all projects anyway, so it's probably a moot point.

values.title: Proposal: Updating to Visual Studio 2017 and improving Windows CI

values.description:
I've added a minimal example of a package that uses ignition-cmake and calls `ign_configure_build` but goes no further. This requires CMakeLists.txt files to exist in the `doc`, `include`, `src`, and `test` folders.

I also used `ExternalProject_Add` so that the examples will be built during `make`. I had to do two funky things in 08ccbf3 to allow the external project to `find_package(ignition-cmake0)` without actually installing `ignition-cmake`:

* set the `CMAKE_PREFIX_PATH` in a cmake arg to the external project
* create symlink in build folder to the `cmake` folder in the source. Since the `create_symlink` cmake command is [only supported on UNIX](https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.2/manual/cmake.1.html#unix-specific-command-line-tools), ~~the ExternalProject_Add call is also restricted to UNIX systems~~ the files are copied one-by-one for non-unix systems (25f8aee)
values.title: add an example with ExternalProject

summary.raw:
I've added a minimal example of a package that uses ignition-cmake and calls `ign_configure_build` but goes no further. This requires CMakeLists.txt files to exist in the `doc`, `include`, `src`, and `test` folders.

I also used `ExternalProject_Add` so that the examples will be built during `make`. I had to do two funky things in 08ccbf3 to allow the external project to `find_package(ignition-cmake0)` without actually installing `ignition-cmake`:

* set the `CMAKE_PREFIX_PATH` in a cmake arg to the external project
* create symlink in build folder to the `cmake` folder in the source. Since the `create_symlink` cmake command is [only supported on UNIX](https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.2/manual/cmake.1.html#unix-specific-command-line-tools), ~~the ExternalProject_Add call is also restricted to UNIX systems~~ the files are copied one-by-one for non-unix systems (25f8aee)
summary.html:
I've added a minimal example of a package that uses ignition-cmake and calls ign_configure_build but goes no further. This requires CMakeLists.txt files to exist in the doc, include, src, and test folders.

I also used ExternalProject_Add so that the examples will be built during make. I had to do two funky things in 08ccbf3 to allow the external project to find_package(ignition-cmake0) without actually installing ignition-cmake:

  • set the CMAKE_PREFIX_PATH in a cmake arg to the external project
  • create symlink in build folder to the cmake folder in the source. Since the create_symlink cmake command is only supported on UNIX, the ExternalProject_Add call is also restricted to UNIX systems the files are copied one-by-one for non-unix systems (25f8aee)

values.description:
This PR addresses issue #2.

Currently, this enforces a tilde `~` between the version numbers and the prerelease suffix (which is allowed to be any string).

From cmake's point of view, the prerelease suffix is entirely superficial. This will not really support the ability to have both a prerelease and final release of the same version installed at the same time. (Well, you can have them both installed at the same time, but you cannot use `find_package` in  `cmake` to select the prerelease version instead of the final release version.)
values.title: Adding support for specifying that a version is a prerelease

values.reason: We're turning down this PR in order to sort out some version control issues. It turns out the differences between Mercurial and Git are not superficial.

values.description:
This PR addresses issue #2.

Currently, this enforces a tilde `~` between the version numbers and the prerelease suffix (which is allowed to be any string). We can change this if anyone would prefer that the separator be explicitly specified (e.g. `ign_configure_project(common 0.1.0 VERSION_SUFFIX ~pre)` instead of `ign_configure_project(common 0.1.0 VERSION_SUFFIX pre)`).

From cmake's point of view, the prerelease suffix is entirely superficial. This will not really support the ability to have both a prerelease and final release of the same version installed at the same time. (Well, you can have them both installed at the same time, but you cannot use find_package in cmake to select the prerelease version instead of the final release version.)
values.title: Supporting prerelease versions of ignition projects

From cmake's point of view, the prerelease suffix is entirely superficial. This will not really support the ability to have both a prerelease and final release of the same version installed at the same time. (Well, you can have them both installed at the same time, but you cannot use find_package in cmake to select the prerelease version instead of the final release version.)

This PR addresses issue #2.

Currently, this enforces a tilde ~ between the version numbers and the prerelease suffix (which is allowed to be any string). We can change this if anyone would prefer that the separator be explicitly specified (e.g. ign_configure_project(common 0.1.0 VERSION_SUFFIX ~pre) instead of ign_configure_project(common 0.1.0 VERSION_SUFFIX pre)).

From cmake's point of view, the prerelease suffix is entirely superficial. This will not really support the ability to have both a prerelease and final release of the same version installed at the same time. (Well, you can have them both installed at the same time, but you cannot use find_package in cmake to select the prerelease version instead of the final release version.)

values.description:
This pull request is the culmination of several days' worth of research and experimentation to understand the nuances of building libraries on Windows.

[I've created a diagram that lays out my findings.](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/14Ags6mV-xQbN6OIfVOPcvDOW9M2WlgwGls-QYhZe2GQ/edit?usp=sharing) The basic conclusion is as follows:

- Using the dynamic runtimes (`/MDd` or `/MD`) allows us to have a robust and comprehensive plugin-based framework which would be prohibitive or impossible if we were to use the static runtimes (`/MTd` or `/MT`).

- The choice between compiling static libraries (`.lib`) vs dynamic libraries (`.dll`) only really affects the way we (or users) want to distribute the binary files. That choice has no impact on the features that we are able to support.

- I suggest that our CI choose the debug dynamic runtime `/MDd` and compile dynamic libraries (`.dll`) because those choices will be the most informative in the event of a CI failure (specifically, if we forgot to apply visibility macros to any classes, that is something which may get caught when the CI is compiling `.dll`s, but it would be completely missed if the CI compiled static `.lib`s).

- I suggest that when it comes time to distribute the libraries as binaries on Windows (...if this is even something we intend to do...) we should distribute them as static libraries (`.lib`).

This pull request doesn't do very much, but it might provide a useful forum for discussing these findings, especially if anyone has questions or concerns.
values.title: Finalize settings for Windows

summary.raw:
This pull request is the culmination of several days' worth of research and experimentation to understand the nuances of building libraries on Windows.

[I've created a diagram that lays out my findings.](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/14Ags6mV-xQbN6OIfVOPcvDOW9M2WlgwGls-QYhZe2GQ/edit?usp=sharing) The basic conclusion is as follows:

- Using the dynamic runtimes (`/MDd` or `/MD`) allows us to have a robust and comprehensive plugin-based framework which would be prohibitive or impossible if we were to use the static runtimes (`/MTd` or `/MT`).

- The choice between compiling static libraries (`.lib`) vs dynamic libraries (`.dll`) only really affects the way we (or users) want to distribute the binary files. That choice has no impact on the features that we are able to support.

- I suggest that our CI choose the debug dynamic runtime `/MDd` and compile dynamic libraries (`.dll`) because those choices will be the most informative in the event of a CI failure (specifically, if we forgot to apply visibility macros to any classes, that is something which may get caught when the CI is compiling `.dll`s, but it would be completely missed if the CI compiled static `.lib`s).

- I suggest that when it comes time to distribute the libraries as binaries on Windows (...if this is even something we intend to do...) we should distribute them as static libraries (`.lib`).

This pull request doesn't do very much, but it might provide a useful forum for discussing these findings, especially if anyone has questions or concerns.
summary.html:
This pull request is the culmination of several days' worth of research and experimentation to understand the nuances of building libraries on Windows.

I've created a diagram that lays out my findings. The basic conclusion is as follows:

  • Using the dynamic runtimes (/MDd or /MD) allows us to have a robust and comprehensive plugin-based framework which would be prohibitive or impossible if we were to use the static runtimes (/MTd or /MT).

  • The choice between compiling static libraries (.lib) vs dynamic libraries (.dll) only really affects the way we (or users) want to distribute the binary files. That choice has no impact on the features that we are able to support.

  • I suggest that our CI choose the debug dynamic runtime /MDd and compile dynamic libraries (.dll) because those choices will be the most informative in the event of a CI failure (specifically, if we forgot to apply visibility macros to any classes, that is something which may get caught when the CI is compiling .dlls, but it would be completely missed if the CI compiled static .libs).

  • I suggest that when it comes time to distribute the libraries as binaries on Windows (...if this is even something we intend to do...) we should distribute them as static libraries (.lib).

This pull request doesn't do very much, but it might provide a useful forum for discussing these findings, especially if anyone has questions or concerns.

values.description:
This addresses issue #7.

Note that once this change has been merged, all downstream users of `ign-cmake` will need to change their top-level `CMakeLists.txt` so that they make a literal call to the `project(~)` command.

Sibling pull requests:

* #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/pull-requests/215/using-a-literal-call-to-the-cmake-project/diff
* #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/pull-requests/84/using-a-literal-call-to-the-cmake-project/diff
* #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/pull-requests/46/using-a-literal-call-to-the-cmake-project/diff
values.title: We now require a literal call to project(~) before calling ign_configure_project(~)

I found this while investigating some problems in the pkg-config file for the ignition-common 0.5.0~pre1 prerelease.

values.description:
It turns out that the pkg-config file format (.pc) requires spaces between the package name, the version comparison operator, and the version number being compared against.  CMake is agnostic towards having those spaces or leaving them out, however we need to use quotes when calling our `ign_pkg_check_modules` macro to ensure that our auto-generated `*.pc` files get filled in correctly.

This also fixes a potential future bug where some packages might have missed out on having their pkg-config information filled in.
values.title: Fix usage of IgnPkgConfig

summary.raw:
It turns out that the pkg-config file format (.pc) requires spaces between the package name, the version comparison operator, and the version number being compared against.  CMake is agnostic towards having those spaces or leaving them out, however we need to use quotes when calling our `ign_pkg_check_modules` macro to ensure that our auto-generated `*.pc` files get filled in correctly.

This also fixes a potential future bug where some packages might have missed out on having their pkg-config information filled in.
summary.html:
It turns out that the pkg-config file format (.pc) requires spaces between the package name, the version comparison operator, and the version number being compared against. CMake is agnostic towards having those spaces or leaving them out, however we need to use quotes when calling our ign_pkg_check_modules macro to ensure that our auto-generated *.pc files get filled in correctly.

This also fixes a potential future bug where some packages might have missed out on having their pkg-config information filled in.

values.description:
It turns out that it's not very safe to assume that most of our dependencies will provide pkg-config (.pc) meta-data. Therefore, this PR modifies the default behavior of `ign_find_package(~)` so that it doesn't make any assumptions about how to fill in the pkg-config entry of a package. Instead, it will rely entirely on the find-modules and/or the caller of `ign_find_package(~)` to provide the necessary information, and it will emit an "author warning" if that information is not provided. In cases where we knowingly do not want to include pkg-config information for a dependency, we can explicitly suppress this using `PKCONFIG_IGNORE`.

This does not negatively impact any projects that are currently using `ign-cmake`, but it will help `ign-common` to fill in its pkg-config information correctly.
values.title: More sensible default behavior for pkg-config entries

summary.raw:
It turns out that it's not very safe to assume that most of our dependencies will provide pkg-config (.pc) meta-data. Therefore, this PR modifies the default behavior of `ign_find_package(~)` so that it doesn't make any assumptions about how to fill in the pkg-config entry of a package. Instead, it will rely entirely on the find-modules and/or the caller of `ign_find_package(~)` to provide the necessary information, and it will emit an "author warning" if that information is not provided. In cases where we knowingly do not want to include pkg-config information for a dependency, we can explicitly suppress this using `PKCONFIG_IGNORE`.

This does not negatively impact any projects that are currently using `ign-cmake`, but it will help `ign-common` to fill in its pkg-config information correctly.
summary.html:
It turns out that it's not very safe to assume that most of our dependencies will provide pkg-config (.pc) meta-data. Therefore, this PR modifies the default behavior of ign_find_package(~) so that it doesn't make any assumptions about how to fill in the pkg-config entry of a package. Instead, it will rely entirely on the find-modules and/or the caller of ign_find_package(~) to provide the necessary information, and it will emit an "author warning" if that information is not provided. In cases where we knowingly do not want to include pkg-config information for a dependency, we can explicitly suppress this using PKCONFIG_IGNORE.

This does not negatively impact any projects that are currently using ign-cmake, but it will help ign-common to fill in its pkg-config information correctly.

values.description:
For some reason, the FindZeroMQ cmake module has specific versions of the software in a list when using windows. When a new version of zeromq is used, we may need to update this list. I just added the stable release versions 4.0.8, 4.1.6, and 4.2.2 from http://zeromq.org/intro:get-the-software

I'd like to use the latest stable release for windows (4.2.2), which requires this change.
values.title: Find more stable release versions of zeromq on Windows

values.description:
This PR should help to catch some typos that I encountered in `ign-msgs` and which might end up occurring elsewhere.

If you pass `SOURCE <sources>` into `ign_build_tests( ... )` instead of `SOURCES <sources>`, it would interpret that as though there aren't any source files for tests. With this PR, `ign_build_tests(~)` will recognize when `SOURCE` is use instead of `SOURCES`, and it will produce an "author warning" while keeping the behavior the same. This should help us catch this typo if it's occurring anywhere else (or if it pops up again in the future).
values.title: Catch (almost) all typos that are passed to ign-cmake functions or macros

summary.raw:
This PR should help to catch some typos that I encountered in `ign-msgs` and which might end up occurring elsewhere.

If you pass `SOURCE <sources>` into `ign_build_tests( ... )` instead of `SOURCES <sources>`, it would interpret that as though there aren't any source files for tests. With this PR, `ign_build_tests(~)` will recognize when `SOURCE` is use instead of `SOURCES`, and it will produce an "author warning" while keeping the behavior the same. This should help us catch this typo if it's occurring anywhere else (or if it pops up again in the future).
summary.html:
This PR should help to catch some typos that I encountered in ign-msgs and which might end up occurring elsewhere.

If you pass SOURCE <sources> into ign_build_tests( ... ) instead of SOURCES <sources>, it would interpret that as though there aren't any source files for tests. With this PR, ign_build_tests(~) will recognize when SOURCE is use instead of SOURCES, and it will produce an "author warning" while keeping the behavior the same. This should help us catch this typo if it's occurring anywhere else (or if it pops up again in the future).

values.description: This resolves an issue that was discussed [here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/pull-requests/2/creating-project-components-ready-for/activity#comment-51874084). Our current implementation for importing targets does not work correctly if there are meant to be multiple include directories for a package. This scenario is rare enough that it hasn't impacted us yet, but it could be very harmful if we ever do need multiple include directories.
values.title: Enable imported target properties to be set to lists

summary.raw: This resolves an issue that was discussed [here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/pull-requests/2/creating-project-components-ready-for/activity#comment-51874084). Our current implementation for importing targets does not work correctly if there are meant to be multiple include directories for a package. This scenario is rare enough that it hasn't impacted us yet, but it could be very harmful if we ever do need multiple include directories.

values.description: I can't find any indication that pkg-config is able to support version suffixes like `~pre#`, `~alpha`, or `~beta`, so I think the safest thing to do is keep them out of our projects' `pkg-config` (.pc) files.
values.title: Do not use prerelease suffixes in pkg-config (.pc) files

summary.raw: I can't find any indication that pkg-config is able to support version suffixes like `~pre#`, `~alpha`, or `~beta`, so I think the safest thing to do is keep them out of our projects' `pkg-config` (.pc) files.
summary.html: I can't find any indication that pkg-config is able to support version suffixes like ~pre#, ~alpha, or ~beta, so I think the safest thing to do is keep them out of our projects' pkg-config (.pc) files.

values.description:
CMake's `find_package(<pkg> <version>)` command gives an error when `<version>` contains a prerelease suffix, such as the `~pre1` in `0.6.0~pre1`. This means that users are not allowed to specify prerelease suffixes when calling `find_package(~)`.

On top of that, cmake's basic version-checking files are not designed to handle our prerelease suffixes, so the `EXACT` command will always fail to find a prerelease package.

This PR will generate the version-checking files without giving them any knowledge of the suffix. Effectively, cmake will make no differentiation between a stable release and a prerelease.
values.title: Do not use the suffix for the basic version-checking file

summary.raw:
CMake's `find_package(<pkg> <version>)` command gives an error when `<version>` contains a prerelease suffix, such as the `~pre1` in `0.6.0~pre1`. This means that users are not allowed to specify prerelease suffixes when calling `find_package(~)`.

On top of that, cmake's basic version-checking files are not designed to handle our prerelease suffixes, so the `EXACT` command will always fail to find a prerelease package.

This PR will generate the version-checking files without giving them any knowledge of the suffix. Effectively, cmake will make no differentiation between a stable release and a prerelease.
summary.html:
CMake's find_package(<pkg> <version>) command gives an error when <version> contains a prerelease suffix, such as the ~pre1 in 0.6.0~pre1. This means that users are not allowed to specify prerelease suffixes when calling find_package(~).

On top of that, cmake's basic version-checking files are not designed to handle our prerelease suffixes, so the EXACT command will always fail to find a prerelease package.

This PR will generate the version-checking files without giving them any knowledge of the suffix. Effectively, cmake will make no differentiation between a stable release and a prerelease.

values.description:
I merged pull request #35 to make it easier to test, but there was a problem with the manual path search for json.h. Adding a `json/` prefix lets fuel-tools find jsoncpp on windows (we haven't compiled the other dependencies yet though, so it's expected to fail):

* https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_fuel-tools-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/36
values.title: FindJSON: find_path json/json.h

values.description: The current release of yaml (0.1.7) only builds a static library, which requires a compile definition `YAML_DECLARE_STATIC` on windows (see [yaml.h](https://github.com/yaml/libyaml/blob/0.1.7/include/yaml.h#L29-L36)).  So set this variable during manual search, which we assume is on windows.
values.title: set YAML_DECLARE_STATIC during manual search

summary.raw: The current release of yaml (0.1.7) only builds a static library, which requires a compile definition `YAML_DECLARE_STATIC` on windows (see [yaml.h](https://github.com/yaml/libyaml/blob/0.1.7/include/yaml.h#L29-L36)).  So set this variable during manual search, which we assume is on windows.
summary.html: The current release of yaml (0.1.7) only builds a static library, which requires a compile definition YAML_DECLARE_STATIC on windows (see yaml.h). So set this variable during manual search, which we assume is on windows.

values.description:
The latest branch of libyaml provides a cmake config file, so try finding it first. Also add a `YAML_TARGET` variable since the new version calls the target `yaml`:

* https://github.com/yaml/libyaml/blob/master/CMakeLists.txt#L55

I could use some advice from @mxgrey on how to do this properly.

Also, the latest branch of libyaml doesn't configure a `.pc` file when you build with cmake, even though it has a template. I've created an issue upstream:

* https://github.com/yaml/libyaml/issues/101
values.title: Find libyaml cmake config (latest unreleased code)

* https://github.com/yaml/libyaml/blob/master/CMakeLists.txt#L55

I could use some advice from @mxgrey on how to do this properly.

Also, the latest branch of libyaml doesn't configure a `.pc` file when you build with cmake, even though it has a template. I've created an issue upstream:

* https://github.com/yaml/libyaml/issues/101

The latest branch of libyaml provides a cmake config file, so try finding it first. Also add a YAML_TARGET variable since the new version calls the target yaml:

I could use some advice from @mxgrey on how to do this properly.

Also, the latest branch of libyaml doesn't configure a .pc file when you build with cmake, even though it has a template. I've created an issue upstream:

values.description:
This PR is a revision of the `Components` branch which brings some improvements for the names of imported targets. It also introduces some "meta-targets" called `requested` and `all`.

I'm doing this in a separate PR and targeting the `Components` branch for two reasons:

1. To keep terminology consistent, the "main" library is being redubbed the "core" library. This means the function `ign_create_main_library(~)` will now be named `ign_create_core_library(~)`. This breaks the API of the `Components` branch, so I wanted to alert @iche033 and any other current users of Components about this before merging it. I'd rather not do a tic-toc on `ign_create_main_library(~)` since it is not in any release of `ign-cmake` yet.

2. I wanted to make it easier for reviewers to see and understand the stylistic changes that this PR is proposing, and offer feedback in case anyone has a different idea about how to name these targets.

Here's a quick overview of what this PR provides:

* Simpler target names. For example, instead of `ignition-common2::ignition-common2`, a user can simply refer to `ignition-common2::core`:

```
find_package(ignition-common2)

# Old version (still works)
target_link_libraries(foo PUBLIC ignition-common2::ignition-common2)

# New version
target_link_libraries(bar PUBLIC ignition-common2::core)
```

This is even more apparent for library components, e.g. the `graphics` component:

```
find_package(ignition-common2 COMPONENTS graphics)

# Old version (still works)
target_link_libraries(foo PUBLIC ignition-common2::ignition-common2-graphics)

# New version
target_link_libraries(bar PUBLIC ignition-common2::graphics)
```

* A meta-target for requested components, e.g.:

```
find_package(ignition-common2 COMPONENTS graphics av)

# Link to core, graphics, and av all at once:
target_link_libraries(foo PUBLIC ignition-common2::requested)
```

* A meta-target for all components, e.g.:

```
find_package(ignition-common2 COMPONENTS all)

# Link to the core library and all its components:
target_link_libraries(foo PUBLIC ignition-common2::all)
```

I decided to make `::requested` and `::all` separate targets, that way the `::all` target implicitly ensures that all components were searched for, because the `::all` target will not exist unless you specifically request `find_package( ... COMPONENTS all)`.

I appreciate any and all feedback, including any disagreement about the `all` vs `requested` distinction, or alternative names for those targets.
values.title: Nicer imported target names

summary.raw:
This PR is a revision of the `Components` branch which brings some improvements for the names of imported targets. It also introduces some "meta-targets" called `requested` and `all`.

I'm doing this in a separate PR and targeting the `Components` branch for two reasons:

1. To keep terminology consistent, the "main" library is being redubbed the "core" library. This means the function `ign_create_main_library(~)` will now be named `ign_create_core_library(~)`. This breaks the API of the `Components` branch, so I wanted to alert @iche033 and any other current users of Components about this before merging it. I'd rather not do a tic-toc on `ign_create_main_library(~)` since it is not in any release of `ign-cmake` yet.

2. I wanted to make it easier for reviewers to see and understand the stylistic changes that this PR is proposing, and offer feedback in case anyone has a different idea about how to name these targets.

Here's a quick overview of what this PR provides:

* Simpler target names. For example, instead of `ignition-common2::ignition-common2`, a user can simply refer to `ignition-common2::core`:

```
find_package(ignition-common2)

# Old version (still works)
target_link_libraries(foo PUBLIC ignition-common2::ignition-common2)

# New version
target_link_libraries(bar PUBLIC ignition-common2::core)
```

This is even more apparent for library components, e.g. the `graphics` component:

```
find_package(ignition-common2 COMPONENTS graphics)

# Old version (still works)
target_link_libraries(foo PUBLIC ignition-common2::ignition-common2-graphics)

# New version
target_link_libraries(bar PUBLIC ignition-common2::graphics)
```

* A meta-target for requested components, e.g.:

```
find_package(ignition-common2 COMPONENTS graphics av)

# Link to core, graphics, and av all at once:
target_link_libraries(foo PUBLIC ignition-common2::requested)
```

* A meta-target for all components, e.g.:

```
find_package(ignition-common2 COMPONENTS all)

# Link to the core library and all its components:
target_link_libraries(foo PUBLIC ignition-common2::all)
```

I decided to make `::requested` and `::all` separate targets, that way the `::all` target implicitly ensures that all components were searched for, because the `::all` target will not exist unless you specifically request `find_package( ... COMPONENTS all)`.

I appreciate any and all feedback, including any disagreement about the `all` vs `requested` distinction, or alternative names for those targets.
summary.html:
This PR is a revision of the Components branch which brings some improvements for the names of imported targets. It also introduces some "meta-targets" called requested and all.

I'm doing this in a separate PR and targeting the Components branch for two reasons:

  1. To keep terminology consistent, the "main" library is being redubbed the "core" library. This means the function ign_create_main_library(~) will now be named ign_create_core_library(~). This breaks the API of the Components branch, so I wanted to alert @iche033 and any other current users of Components about this before merging it. I'd rather not do a tic-toc on ign_create_main_library(~) since it is not in any release of ign-cmake yet.

  2. I wanted to make it easier for reviewers to see and understand the stylistic changes that this PR is proposing, and offer feedback in case anyone has a different idea about how to name these targets.

Here's a quick overview of what this PR provides:

  • Simpler target names. For example, instead of ignition-common2::ignition-common2, a user can simply refer to ignition-common2::core:
find_package(ignition-common2)

# Old version (still works)
target_link_libraries(foo PUBLIC ignition-common2::ignition-common2)

# New version
target_link_libraries(bar PUBLIC ignition-common2::core)

This is even more apparent for library components, e.g. the graphics component:

find_package(ignition-common2 COMPONENTS graphics)

# Old version (still works)
target_link_libraries(foo PUBLIC ignition-common2::ignition-common2-graphics)

# New version
target_link_libraries(bar PUBLIC ignition-common2::graphics)
  • A meta-target for requested components, e.g.:
find_package(ignition-common2 COMPONENTS graphics av)

# Link to core, graphics, and av all at once:
target_link_libraries(foo PUBLIC ignition-common2::requested)
  • A meta-target for all components, e.g.:
find_package(ignition-common2 COMPONENTS all)

# Link to the core library and all its components:
target_link_libraries(foo PUBLIC ignition-common2::all)

I decided to make ::requested and ::all separate targets, that way the ::all target implicitly ensures that all components were searched for, because the ::all target will not exist unless you specifically request find_package( ... COMPONENTS all).

I appreciate any and all feedback, including any disagreement about the all vs requested distinction, or alternative names for those targets.

values.description:
Fixes [this ign-common issue](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/issues/30/windows-warning-could-not-find-pkg-config). The windows code path wasn't setting the pkg-config library entry. I fix that in 9ba6990, then refactor the code a bit in b7824a3 to reduce code duplication, since there are two blocks of identical code used in the windows and unix codepaths. With the refactoring, it's helpful to view the diff without whitespace:

* #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/pull-requests/47/finddl-fix-windows-warning/diff?w=1
values.title: FindDL: fix windows warning

values.description:
@iche033  this should fix the issue with the master header.

However, I'm making this a separate PR because it requires an API change:

Everywhere that you were using

```
ign_install_all_headers(COMPONENT ...)
```

Needs to be changed to

```
ign_install_all_headers(COMPONENT <component_name> ...)
```

i.e. you need to explicitly state the component name instead of just specifying `COMPONENT`. It's kind of a nuisance, but it's the most straightforward fix that I can think of at the moment.

Feel free to merge this PR once your branch in `ign-rendering` is compatible with it.
values.title: Component Master Header

summary.html:
@iche033 this should fix the issue with the master header.

However, I'm making this a separate PR because it requires an API change:

Everywhere that you were using

ign_install_all_headers(COMPONENT ...)

Needs to be changed to

ign_install_all_headers(COMPONENT <component_name> ...)

i.e. you need to explicitly state the component name instead of just specifying COMPONENT. It's kind of a nuisance, but it's the most straightforward fix that I can think of at the moment.

Feel free to merge this PR once your branch in ign-rendering is compatible with it.

values.description:
I'm creating a temporary pull request for this change, because it represents a significant departure from the way our binary directories have been structured up until now.

This shouldn't have a noticeable impact for users, except that executables and libraries will probably be much easier to find within the build directories.

The main thing this impacts is tests which need to call on executables or libraries at runtime. This means `ign-common` will need to be updated (it already has been, on the [Components branch](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/branch/Components)), and `ign-transport` will need to be updated (I'll take care of that as soon as I'm done with this PR). I'm not aware of any other live ignition projects that are impacted by this.

Since this change is not backwards compatible with `ign-common` or `ign-transport`, I'm officially incrementing the major version. All other ignition projects should still be compatible with this change, and all the other backwards compatibility features of `ign-cmake` will remain, so that it's easy for the various projects to migrate.

### Motivation

The principle motivation behind this change is to have much much much cleaner support for Windows. Up until now, we've been doing a gross hack where we copy the DLL of the core library into the directories where the test executables are generated. This was necessary in order to make the DLL visible to those executables (which is a requirement of Windows, since Windows doesn't do hard linking to libraries).

This becomes untenable once components are introduced, because suddenly we have to copy the core library DLL to every test directory, including the component test directories, and we also have to copy each component DLL to every test directory that depends on it. Not only is this incredibly wasteful of hard drive space, but it becomes very tricky to keep track of all the libraries and all the directories that they need to be copied to.

This is trivially solved by putting all runtime objects (executables and DLLs) into one directory. Library files can be put into their own directory so that we have a bit of organization.

As an added benefit, this vaguely reflects a typical UNIX system file structure, so I think it'll be more familiar to people who need to root around in the build directory.
values.title: Consolidate the binary output directories

I'm creating a temporary pull request for this change, because it represents a significant departure from the way our binary directories have been structured up until now.

This shouldn't have a noticeable impact for users, except that executables and libraries will probably be much easier to find within the build directories.

The main thing this impacts is tests which need to call on executables or libraries at runtime. This means ign-common will need to be updated (it already has been, on the Components branch), and ign-transport will need to be updated (I'll take care of that as soon as I'm done with this PR). I'm not aware of any other live ignition projects that are impacted by this.

Since this change is not backwards compatible with ign-common or ign-transport, I'm officially incrementing the major version. All other ignition projects should still be compatible with this change, and all the other backwards compatibility features of ign-cmake will remain, so that it's easy for the various projects to migrate.

Motivation

The principle motivation behind this change is to have much much much cleaner support for Windows. Up until now, we've been doing a gross hack where we copy the DLL of the core library into the directories where the test executables are generated. This was necessary in order to make the DLL visible to those executables (which is a requirement of Windows, since Windows doesn't do hard linking to libraries).
